sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for PFV inflection: 3sg.f in sound verbs .

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found
updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

cit.quote: kull in-nās žāʕat ʔilla lə-bduwi ma yižūʕ
everyone suffered hunger except for Bedouins

wib:featureValueObservation.note: the author only provides the prefixes and suffixes, no declinations
Palva only gives the inflectional edings for the strong verb
Both examples are taken from Panetta (1943)
If preceding an object suffix, the verbal suffix would be -at, e.g. ḏ̣arbathum 'she hit them'
The suffix -at is used after ʕ, ḥ and emphatic sounds, e.g. simaʕat (she heard).
In form I verbs of the i-type the inflectional suffix is -it, ex: širibit
The pattern changes from CaCaCat to CaCCa
In form I verbs of the i-type the inflectional suffix is -it, ex: širibit
